column1: Rh incompatibility is a condition that develops when a pregnant woman has Rh-negative blood and the baby in her womb has Rh-positive blood.
These antibodies may cross back through the placenta into the developing baby.
Firstborn infants are often not affected unless the mother had past miscarriages or abortions that sensitized her immune system.
There may be: - A positive direct Coombs test result - Higher-than-normal levels of bilirubin in the baby's umbilical cord blood - Signs of red blood cell destruction in the infant's blood
Therefore, prevention remains the best treatment.
Infants with mild Rh incompatibility may be treated with phototherapy using bilirubin lights.
This is to decrease the levels of bilirubin in the blood.

Complications may include: - Brain damage due to high levels of bilirubin (kernicterus) - Fluid buildup and swelling in the baby (hydrops fetalis) - Problems with mental function, movement, hearing, speech, and seizures
Special immune globulins, called RhoGAM, are now used to prevent RH incompatibility in mothers who are Rh-negative.
If the father of the infant is Rh-positive or if his blood type is not known, the mother is given an injection of RhoGAM during the second trimester.
